title: Game Development
summary: Create Interactive entertainment experiences across PC, consoles, mobile, and VR/AR platforms using Unity or Unreal Engine.

steps.title: Programming Basics - C# or C++ (6-8 weeks)
steps.description: Master C# for Unity or C++ for Unreal Engine. Learn object-oriented programming, data structures, and game-specific programming patterns.

quiz.question: What is C#?
quiz.explanation: C# is primary scripting language for Unity games.

quiz.question: What is C++?
quiz.explanation: C++ offers low-level control for game performance.

quiz.question: What is OOP?
options: Object-Oriented Programming with classes and objects
quiz.explanation: OOP organizes code into reusable classes and objects.

quiz.question: What is a class?
quiz.explanation: Classes define properties and methods for objects.

quiz.question: What is inheritance?
quiz.explanation: Inheritance enables code reuse and hierarchy.

quiz.question: What is polymorphism?
options: Objects taking multiple forms through inheritance
quiz.explanation: Polymorphism allows method overriding and interfaces.

quiz.question: What is a data structure?
options: Way to organize and store data
quiz.explanation: Data structures include arrays, lists, stacks, queues, trees.

quiz.question: What is an array?
options: Collection of elements of same type
quiz.explanation: Arrays store multiple values with indexed access.

quiz.question: What is a loop?
options: Repeating code block until condition met
quiz.explanation: Loops include for, while, and foreach for iteration.

quiz.question: What is debugging?
quiz.explanation: Debugging uses breakpoints, logs, and step-through.

quiz.question: What is encapsulation?
options: Hiding internal details using access modifiers
quiz.explanation: Encapsulation uses private/public to protect data.

quiz.question: What is a method?
options: Function inside a class defining behavior
quiz.explanation: Methods perform actions and can return values.

quiz.question: What is a variable?
quiz.explanation: Variables have types: int, float, string, bool.

quiz.question: What are conditional statements?
options: Statements controlling flow based on conditions
quiz.explanation: Conditionals include if, else if, else, switch.

quiz.question: What is a function?
options: Reusable block of code performing task
quiz.explanation: Functions take parameters and return values.

quiz.question: What is a string?
quiz.explanation: Strings support concatenation, formatting, manipulation.

quiz.question: What is a list?
quiz.explanation: Lists can grow/shrink with Add(), Remove() methods.

quiz.question: What is a dictionary/map?
options: Key-value pair collection for fast lookup
quiz.explanation: Dictionaries map keys to values for efficient access.

quiz.question: What is exception handling?
quiz.explanation: Exception handling prevents crashes from errors.

quiz.question: What is static vs instance?
options: Static belongs to class, instance to object
quiz.explanation: Static members shared across all instances.

steps.title: Game Design Fundamentals (2-3 weeks)
steps.description: Learn game design principles, level design, game mechanics, balancing, and the MDA framework (Mechanics, Dynamics, Aesthetics).

resources.title: The Art of Game Design Book

quiz.question: What is game design?
quiz.explanation: Game design defines how players interact with the game.

quiz.question: What are game mechanics?
quiz.explanation: Mechanics include movement, combat, inventory, progression.

quiz.question: What is level design?
options: Creating environments and challenges for players
quiz.explanation: Level design guides player flow and pacing.

quiz.question: What is the MDA framework?
quiz.explanation: MDA analyzes game design from different perspectives.

quiz.question: What is game balancing?
quiz.explanation: Balancing ensures fun, fair, and engaging gameplay.

quiz.question: What is a game loop?
options: Core cycle of input, update, render
quiz.explanation: Game loop runs continuously during gameplay.

quiz.question: What is player feedback?
quiz.explanation: Feedback makes actions feel responsive and satisfying.

quiz.question: What is progression system?
options: Mechanics for player advancement and rewards
quiz.explanation: Progression includes XP, levels, unlocks, achievements.

quiz.question: What is difficulty curve?
options: Gradual increase in challenge over time
quiz.explanation: Good curve matches player skill growth.

quiz.question: What is playtesting?
options: Testing game with real players for feedback
quiz.explanation: Playtesting reveals issues and guides improvements.

quiz.question: What is the fun factor?
options: Elements making game enjoyable and engaging
quiz.explanation: Fun comes from challenge, discovery, mastery, social.

quiz.question: What is challenge vs skill balance?
options: Matching game difficulty to player ability
quiz.explanation: Balance creates flow state, avoiding boredom/frustration.

quiz.question: What is a core loop?
options: Repeating cycle of actions players perform
quiz.explanation: Core loop: shoot enemies → earn points → upgrade → repeat.

quiz.question: What is emergent gameplay?
options: Unexpected behaviors from simple rules interaction
quiz.explanation: Emergent gameplay creates player-driven stories.

quiz.question: What are game genres?
options: Categories: FPS, RPG, platformer, puzzle, strategy
quiz.explanation: Genres define gameplay style and expectations.

quiz.question: What is a tutorial?
quiz.explanation: Good tutorials integrate teaching into gameplay.

quiz.question: What is onboarding?
options: Process introducing new players to game
quiz.explanation: Onboarding gradually reveals mechanics to avoid overwhelm.

quiz.question: What is player motivation?
options: Reasons players engage: achievement, social, exploration
quiz.explanation: Understanding motivation drives design decisions.

quiz.question: What is a game economy?
quiz.explanation: Economy balances earning, spending, progression.

quiz.question: What are reward systems?
options: Mechanisms providing incentives: XP, loot, achievements
quiz.explanation: Rewards create satisfaction and drive progression.

steps.title: Math for Games (2-3 weeks)
steps.description: Master vectors, matrices, transformations, quaternions, and collision detection - essential math concepts for game development.

resources.title: Math for Game Developers - YouTube Series

quiz.question: What is a vector?
quiz.explanation: Vectors represent position, velocity, force in games.

quiz.question: What is dot product?
quiz.explanation: Dot product: A · B = |A||B|cos(θ), used for angles.

quiz.question: What is cross product?
quiz.explanation: Cross product finds normal vectors and rotation axes.

quiz.question: What is a matrix?
quiz.explanation: Matrices perform rotation, scaling, translation.

quiz.question: What is a transformation?
quiz.explanation: Transformations include translate, rotate, scale.

quiz.question: What is a quaternion?
quiz.explanation: Quaternions avoid gimbal lock in 3D rotations.

quiz.question: What is linear interpolation (lerp)?
quiz.explanation: Lerp: value = start + (end - start) * t for smooth movement.

quiz.question: What is collision detection?
options: Determining if objects overlap or intersect
quiz.explanation: Collision uses bounding boxes, spheres, raycasts.

quiz.question: What is a normal vector?
quiz.explanation: Normals are used for lighting and reflections.

quiz.question: What is magnitude?
quiz.explanation: Magnitude: |v| = √(x² + y² + z²) measures distance.

quiz.question: What is a unit vector?
quiz.explanation: Unit vectors indicate direction without distance.

quiz.question: What is vector normalization?
quiz.explanation: Normalize: v_normalized = v / |v| creates unit vector.

quiz.question: What is scalar multiplication?
options: Multiplying vector by number to scale
quiz.explanation: Scalar multiplication changes vector magnitude.

quiz.question: What is matrix multiplication?
quiz.explanation: Matrix multiplication chains multiple transformations.

quiz.question: What is translation?
quiz.explanation: Translation adds offset to position vector.

quiz.question: What is rotation?
quiz.explanation: Rotation uses angles or quaternions for orientation.

quiz.question: What is scale?
options: Changing object size uniformly or non-uniformly
quiz.explanation: Scale multiplies vertex positions from origin.

quiz.question: What is raycasting?
quiz.explanation: Raycasting finds hit points for shooting, clicking.

quiz.question: What are bounding boxes?
quiz.explanation: Bounding boxes optimize collision detection.

quiz.question: What is trigonometry in games?
options: Using sin, cos, tan for angles and circles
quiz.explanation: Trigonometry calculates trajectories, rotations, waves.

steps.title: Unity Basics (4-6 weeks)
steps.description: Learn Unity interface, GameObjects, components, prefabs, scripting API, physics, and 2D/3D game development fundamentals.

quiz.question: What is Unity?
quiz.explanation: Unity supports cross-platform game development.

quiz.question: What is a GameObject?
quiz.explanation: GameObjects hold components defining behavior.

quiz.question: What is a component?
quiz.explanation: Components include Transform, Rigidbody, Collider, scripts.

quiz.question: What is a prefab?
quiz.explanation: Prefabs enable instantiating identical objects.

quiz.question: What is the Transform component?
quiz.explanation: Every GameObject has a Transform component.

quiz.question: What is a Rigidbody?
quiz.explanation: Rigidbody adds gravity, velocity, and forces.

quiz.question: What is a Collider?
options: Component defining physical shape for collisions
quiz.explanation: Colliders include BoxCollider, SphereCollider, MeshCollider.

quiz.question: What is the Unity scripting API?
options: Interface for programming Unity with C#
quiz.explanation: API provides MonoBehaviour, Input, Physics classes.

quiz.question: What is MonoBehaviour?
quiz.explanation: MonoBehaviour provides Start(), Update(), and event methods.

quiz.question: What is the Update() method?
options: Called every frame for game logic
quiz.explanation: Update() runs continuously for input and movement.

quiz.question: What is a scene?
options: Container for game levels and menus
quiz.explanation: Scenes hold GameObjects for different game areas.

quiz.question: What is the Start() method?
quiz.explanation: Start() runs before first frame for initialization.

quiz.question: What is FixedUpdate()?
options: Called at fixed time intervals for physics
quiz.explanation: FixedUpdate() ensures consistent physics simulation.

quiz.question: What is OnCollisionEnter()?
quiz.explanation: OnCollisionEnter() detects physical collisions.

quiz.question: What is the Input system?
quiz.explanation: Input.GetKey(), GetAxis() read player controls.

quiz.question: What is Instantiate()?
options: Creates copy of GameObject at runtime
quiz.explanation: Instantiate() spawns prefabs for bullets, enemies.

quiz.question: What is Destroy()?
quiz.explanation: Destroy() cleans up objects to free memory.

quiz.question: What are tags?
quiz.explanation: Tags enable finding objects: Player, Enemy, Ground.

quiz.question: What are layers?
quiz.explanation: Layers control what objects interact with each other.

quiz.question: What is a physics material?
options: Defines friction and bounciness for colliders
quiz.explanation: Physics materials control surface properties.

steps.title: Unity 2D & 3D Development (7-10 weeks)
steps.description: Master 2D sprites, animations, tilemaps, and 3D modeling, lighting, materials, camera controls, NavMesh AI, and pArticle systems.

quiz.question: What is a sprite?
quiz.explanation: Sprites are used for characters, backgrounds, UI.

quiz.question: What is an animation?
quiz.explanation: Animation uses Animator and keyframes.

quiz.question: What is a tilemap?
quiz.explanation: Tilemaps efficiently create platformer levels.

quiz.question: What is 3D modeling?
options: Creating 3D objects with vertices and faces
quiz.explanation: 3D models use Blender, Maya, or Unity ProBuilder.

quiz.question: What is lighting?
quiz.explanation: Lighting includes directional, point, spot lights.

quiz.question: What is a material?
quiz.explanation: Materials use shaders for rendering effects.

quiz.question: What is a camera?
quiz.explanation: Cameras have perspective or orthographic projection.

quiz.question: What is NavMesh?
quiz.explanation: NavMesh enables AI to navigate around obstacles.

quiz.question: What is a pArticle system?
quiz.explanation: PArticles create fire, smoke, explosions, magic.

quiz.question: What is URP?
options: Universal Render Pipeline for optimized rendering
quiz.explanation: URP improves performance for mobile and lower-end devices.

quiz.question: What is a SpriteRenderer?
quiz.explanation: SpriteRenderer shows sprites with sorting order.

quiz.question: What is the Animator component?
quiz.explanation: Animator manages state machines and transitions.

quiz.question: What is a tilemap collider?
quiz.explanation: Tilemap collider optimizes 2D level collisions.

quiz.question: What is a mesh?
options: Collection of vertices, edges, faces for 3D
quiz.explanation: Meshes define 3D object geometry.

quiz.question: What is a texture?
quiz.explanation: Textures add color and detail to materials.

quiz.question: What are normal maps?
options: Textures simulating surface detail without geometry
quiz.explanation: Normal maps add depth illusion through lighting.

quiz.question: What is a skybox?
quiz.explanation: Skybox creates distant environment around scene.

quiz.question: What is post-processing?
options: Effects applied after rendering: bloom, blur, color grading
quiz.explanation: Post-processing enhances visual quality.

quiz.question: What is terrain?
options: System for creating landscapes with height maps
quiz.explanation: Terrain tools sculpt, paint, add trees/grass.

quiz.question: What is ragdoll physics?
options: Physics-based character animation for realistic falls
quiz.explanation: Ragdoll uses joints and rigidbodies for death animations.

steps.title: Unity Advanced Topics (4-6 weeks)
steps.description: Learn animation controllers, UI systems, audio mixing, performance optimization, object pooling, and multiplayer networking.

quiz.question: What is an Animator Controller?
quiz.explanation: Animator uses state machines for character animations.

quiz.question: What is Unity UI?
options: Canvas-based system for menus and HUD
quiz.explanation: UI includes Canvas, Button, Text, Image components.

quiz.question: What is audio mixing?
quiz.explanation: Audio Mixer controls volume, effects, and groups.

quiz.question: What is performance optimization?
options: Improving game speed and reducing lag
quiz.explanation: Optimization includes profiling, LOD, occlusion culling.

quiz.question: What is object pooling?
quiz.explanation: Pooling reduces garbage collection for bullets, enemies.

quiz.question: What is multiplayer networking?
quiz.explanation: Multiplayer uses client-server or peer-to-peer.

quiz.question: What is Netcode for GameObjects?
quiz.explanation: Netcode handles synchronization and RPCs.

quiz.question: What is Photon?
quiz.explanation: Photon provides cloud-hosted multiplayer services.

quiz.question: What is LOD?
options: Level of Detail for optimizing distant objects
quiz.explanation: LOD reduces polygon count based on distance.

quiz.question: What is occlusion culling?
options: Not rendering objects hidden behind others
quiz.explanation: Occlusion culling improves performance by skipping hidden objects.

quiz.question: What are blend trees?
options: Smoothly blending multiple animations based on parameters
quiz.explanation: Blend trees create fluid movement transitions.

quiz.question: What is the Event System?
options: Handles UI interactions and input events
quiz.explanation: Event System manages button clicks, hover, drag.

quiz.question: What is an Audio Source?
options: Component playing sound clips in 3D space
quiz.explanation: Audio Source has volume, pitch, spatial blend.

quiz.question: What is the Profiler?
quiz.explanation: Profiler shows CPU, GPU, memory, rendering usage.

quiz.question: What is garbage collection?
options: Automatic memory cleanup causing frame drops
quiz.explanation: Minimize GC by avoiding frequent allocations.

quiz.question: What are coroutines?
quiz.explanation: Coroutines use yield for delayed actions.

quiz.question: What are ScriptableObjects?
options: Data containers separate from scene objects
quiz.explanation: ScriptableObjects store shared data efficiently.

quiz.question: What are Addressables?
quiz.explanation: Addressables enable asset streaming and updates.

quiz.question: What is server-client model?
quiz.explanation: Server-client prevents cheating in multiplayer.

quiz.question: What is RPC?
options: Remote Procedure Call for network communication
quiz.explanation: RPC invokes methods across network clients.

steps.title: Unreal Engine Basics & C++ (8-12 weeks)
steps.description: Learn Unreal Engine interface, Blueprint visual scripting, C++ programming for Unreal, materials, Nanite/Lumen, Niagara VFX, and multiplayer.

quiz.question: What is Unreal Engine?
options: Powerful game engine for AAA games
quiz.explanation: Unreal Engine offers photorealistic graphics and scalability.

quiz.question: What is Blueprint?
quiz.explanation: Blueprint uses nodes instead of code for logic.

quiz.question: What is C++ in Unreal?
quiz.explanation: C++ provides more control and optimization than Blueprint.

quiz.question: What is Nanite?
quiz.explanation: Nanite eliminates need for LODs with massive poly counts.

quiz.question: What is Lumen?
quiz.explanation: Lumen provides real-time ray-traced lighting.

quiz.question: What is Niagara?
quiz.explanation: Niagara creates complex pArticle effects efficiently.

quiz.question: What is a Behavior Tree?
quiz.explanation: Behavior Trees control NPC actions and logic.

quiz.question: What is a material in Unreal?
quiz.explanation: Materials use Material Editor for complex effects.

quiz.question: What is MetaHuman?
options: Tool for creating realistic digital humans
quiz.explanation: MetaHuman Creator generates photorealistic characters.

quiz.question: What is Unreal multiplayer?
options: Network replication system for online games
quiz.explanation: Unreal handles server-client architecture with replication.

quiz.question: What is the Unreal Editor?
options: Integrated development environment for creating games
quiz.explanation: Unreal Editor provides viewport, content browser, details panel.

quiz.question: What are actors in Unreal?
options: Base class for objects placed in levels
quiz.explanation: Actors include characters, lights, cameras, meshes.

quiz.question: What are components in Unreal?
quiz.explanation: Components add mesh, collision, movement to actors.

quiz.question: What is GameMode?
options: Defines game rules, win conditions, spawning
quiz.explanation: GameMode controls match flow and player classes.

quiz.question: What is PlayerController?
quiz.explanation: PlayerController handles input and possession.

quiz.question: What is Character Movement Component?
quiz.explanation: Character Movement provides built-in locomotion.

quiz.question: What is the Landscape system?
quiz.explanation: Landscape supports sculpting, painting, streaming.

quiz.question: What is Chaos Physics?
quiz.explanation: Chaos enables realistic destruction and fracturing.

quiz.question: What is Sequencer?
quiz.explanation: Sequencer creates in-game cinematics with timeline.

quiz.question: What are Data Assets?
quiz.explanation: Data Assets define weapons, items, characters.

steps.title: Specialized Topics (6-10 weeks)
steps.description: Master mobile game optimization, VR/AR development, game AI (FSM, pathfinding, behavior trees), shaders, and graphics programming.

quiz.question: What is mobile game optimization?
quiz.explanation: Mobile optimization reduces draw calls, texture size, complexity.

quiz.question: What is VR?
quiz.explanation: VR uses headsets like Meta Quest, PSVR for immersion.

quiz.question: What is AR?
options: Augmented Reality overlaying digital on real world
quiz.explanation: AR uses phones or glasses (ARKit, ARCore).

quiz.question: What is FSM?
options: Finite State Machine for AI behavior
quiz.explanation: FSM manages AI states: idle, patrol, chase, attack.

quiz.question: What is pathfinding?
quiz.explanation: Pathfinding uses A* algorithm for AI navigation.

quiz.question: What is A* algorithm?
quiz.explanation: A* finds shortest path considering obstacles.

quiz.question: What is a shader?
options: Program running on GPU for rendering
quiz.explanation: Shaders control vertex and fragment processing.

quiz.question: What is Shader Graph?
options: Visual shader creation tool in Unity
quiz.explanation: Shader Graph creates shaders without code.

quiz.question: What is Unity ML-Agents?
options: Machine learning toolkit for training AI
quiz.explanation: ML-Agents uses reinforcement learning for intelligent NPCs.

quiz.question: What is a vertex shader?
quiz.explanation: Vertex shaders transform positions and normals.

quiz.question: What are draw calls?
quiz.explanation: Reducing draw calls improves mobile performance.

quiz.question: What are texture atlases?
options: Combining multiple textures into single image
quiz.explanation: Atlases reduce draw calls and memory usage.

quiz.question: What is ARKit/ARCore?
quiz.explanation: ARKit/ARCore provide plane detection, tracking.

quiz.question: What is VR locomotion?
options: Movement methods: teleport, smooth, arm swing
quiz.explanation: Locomotion minimizes motion sickness in VR.

quiz.question: What is hand tracking?
options: Detecting hand positions and gestures in VR
quiz.explanation: Hand tracking enables controller-free interactions.

quiz.question: What are decision trees?
quiz.explanation: Decision trees evaluate conditions for NPC actions.

quiz.question: What is HLSL/GLSL?
quiz.explanation: HLSL (DirectX) and GLSL (OpenGL) write custom shaders.

quiz.question: What is a fragment shader?
quiz.explanation: Fragment shaders apply lighting and textures.

quiz.question: What is procedural generation?
quiz.explanation: Procedural generation creates infinite worlds, dungeons.

quiz.question: What are neural networks in games?
options: AI models learning from gameplay data
quiz.explanation: Neural networks power adaptive AI opponents.

steps.title: Production & Publishing (2-3 weeks)
steps.description: Learn game polish techniques, monetization strategies, build optimization, and publishing to Steam, Epic Games Store, App Store, and Google Play.

quiz.question: What is game polish?
options: Refining details for quality and feel
quiz.explanation: Polish includes animations, pArticles, sound, feedback.

quiz.question: What is monetization?
options: Strategies to earn revenue from game
quiz.explanation: Monetization includes ads, in-app purchases, premium.

quiz.question: What is build optimization?
options: Reducing game size and improving performance
quiz.explanation: Optimization compresses assets, removes unused code.

quiz.question: What is Steam?
quiz.explanation: Steam is largest digital PC game store.

quiz.question: What is Epic Games Store?
options: Game distribution platform by Epic Games
quiz.explanation: Epic Store offers competitive revenue split for developers.

quiz.question: What is itch.io?
quiz.explanation: itch.io supports independent developers with flexible pricing.

quiz.question: What are Unity Ads?
quiz.explanation: Unity Ads displays Video/banner ads in games.

quiz.question: What is in-app purchase?
quiz.explanation: IAP sells coins, skins, power-ups, subscriptions.

quiz.question: What is a game jam?
options: Event where developers create game in limited time
quiz.explanation: Game jams (Ludum Dare, Global Game Jam) foster creativity.

quiz.question: What is Asset Store?
options: Marketplace for game assets and tools
quiz.explanation: Asset Store sells 3D models, scripts, audio, plugins.

quiz.question: What is compression?
options: Reducing file sizes for faster loading
quiz.explanation: Compression uses texture/audio compression formats.

quiz.question: What are platform-specific builds?
options: Compiling for PC, consoles, mobile separately
quiz.explanation: Each platform has unique requirements and SDKs.

quiz.question: What are achievements?
quiz.explanation: Achievements integrate with Steam, Xbox, PlayStation.

quiz.question: What are leaderboards?
quiz.explanation: Leaderboards encourage competition and replayability.

quiz.question: What are cloud saves?
options: Saving game progress to cloud storage
quiz.explanation: Cloud saves sync progress across devices.

quiz.question: What is DLC?
quiz.explanation: DLC includes expansions, skins, levels, characters.

quiz.question: What are patches?
options: Updates fixing bugs and balancing gameplay
quiz.explanation: Patches maintain game quality post-launch.

quiz.question: What is version control?
options: System tracking code changes over time
quiz.explanation: Version control enables collaboration and rollback.

quiz.question: What is Git?
options: Popular version control system for developers
quiz.explanation: Git uses branches, commits, merges for teamwork.

quiz.question: What is game marketing?
options: Promoting game through trailers, social media, press
quiz.explanation: Marketing builds community and drives wishlists/sales.

projects.title: 2D Platformer Game
projects.description: Create a classic 2D platformer game with player movement, jumping mechanics, collectibles, enemies, and multiple levels.
tasks: Set up Unity project with 2D settings
Add collision detection and death mechanics
Add sound effects and background music
Build start menu and game over screen

projects.title: 3D First-Person Shooter
projects.description: Develop a 3D FPS game with shooting mechanics, enemy AI, health system, multiple weapons, and level progression.
tasks: Create weapon system with different guns
Implement UI for health, ammo, and score

projects.title: Multiplayer Battle Arena Game
projects.description: Build a multiplayer arena game with real-time networking, character selection, abilities, and matchmaking system.
tasks: Set up Photon Unity Networking or Mirror
Implement player connection and lobby system
Develop multiple characters with unique abilities
Add health bars and damage indicators

projects.title: Open World RPG
projects.description: Create an ambitious open-world RPG with quest system, inventory, crafting, NPCs, dialogue trees, and procedural terrain generation.
tasks: Create enemy AI with behavior trees

projects.title: VR Escape Room Game
projects.description: Develop a fully immersive VR escape room game with hand interactions, physics-based puzzles, environmental storytelling, and haptic feedback.
tasks: Set up Unity XR Toolkit for VR
Create hand tracking and grab mechanics
